newsitem.title: USA: Pan Am expects to fly this month after merger vote.
newsitem.headline: Pan Am expects to fly this month after merger vote.

text.p: Pan American World Airways said Wednesday that shareholders of the Frost Hanna Mergers Group Inc had voted to merge the two companies into a single entity to be called Pan Am Corp.
The defunct airline said it planned to return to the skies later this month following the vote.

"We would expect to consummate the merger and be in the air this month," it said. "Frost Hanna's involvement provides Pan Am with an additional $10 million in cash and is a key part of the $40 million financing we have raised to launch a serious, high quality airline."
Pan Am said the new entity would likely become a publicly-traded company on the American Stock Exchange.
The airline, temporarily headquartered in Miami, said it would begin service with A300 Airbus wide-bodied aircrafts with daily flights between New York-Miami and New York-Los Angeles.
It would later add San Francisco, Chicago and San Juan during the first year of operation, it added.
The heavily indebted airline, one of the world's aviation pioneers, collapsed in 1991.
Two years later, Florida businessmen Chuck Cobb and Martin Shugrue bought its name and logo with the intent of eventually resurrecting the airline.
